interval.label: Service Check Interval
interval.description: How often to service-check the instance.

timeout.label: Request Timeout
timeout.description: How long to wait for a response from the instance.

validSsl.label: Validate SSL Certificate
validSsl.description: Checking the box makes sure the instance is using a valid SSL certificate.

deletes.label: Delete Content
deletes.description: This limits the number of delete requests that may be sent to this instance in an hour.
deletes.tooltip: This controls how many delete requests are allowed per hour. A setting of 0 disables the ability to send delete requests. This refers to media deletes, but may include other actions. This is a throttle to prevent hackers from obliterating your content.

phrases.ConfirmReloadBody: Are you sure you want to reload the client?
phrases.ReloadCheckTimedOut: Server reload check timed out after 20 attempts
phrases.ConfirmShutdownBody: Are you sure you want to shutdown the client? You will need to restart it from the host it runs on.
phrases.FailedToShutdown: Failed to shutdown: {error} - Try reloading the page.
phrases.LoginHelpBody: If you've forgotten your password, please see the forgotten passwords wiki page. If this is your first time logging in you can find your password in the client log file. If you provided an API key to the client before starting it for the first time, then your password is the API key.

Landing.SelectASection: Select a section from the navigation menu to get started.

pageDescription.Configuration: Configure your Notifiarr client settings here.
pageDescription.SiteTunnel: Select primary and secondary tunnel servers.
pageDescription.MediaApps: Manage media players and related services.
pageDescription.FileWatcher: Watch for file changes and trigger actions.
pageDescription.Endpoints: Configure relay endpoints, timers and triggers.
pageDescription.Commands: Set up and execute custom commands and scripts.
pageDescription.Services: Set up and monitor network devices and services.
pageDescription.Integrations: View action statistics and for all integrations.
pageDescription.Metrics: View metric totals for client configurations.
pageDescription.LogFiles: View and manage client log files.
pageDescription.System: View system and client information and.
pageDescription.TrustProfile: Configure how you log into this Notifiarr client application.
pageDescription.Landing: This is the greatest place on Earth!

errors.PleaseEnterBothUsernameAndPassword: Please enter both username and password.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key from your Notifiarr.com account.
apiKey.tooltip: Find this by logging into Notifiarr.com, go to Profile then API Keys.

extraKeys.label: Extra Keys
extraKeys.description: Additional API keys for third-party integrations. Separate with newlines.

bindAddr.label: Bind Address
bindAddr.description: IP and port the app will listen on. Use 0.0.0.0 to listen on all interfaces.

sslKeyFile.label: SSL Key File
sslKeyFile.tooltip: This application can serve HTTPS. Enable that by specifying a certificate file path and key file path.

sslCertFile.label: SSL Certificate File
sslCertFile.tooltip: This application can serve HTTPS. Enable that by specifying a certificate file path and key file path.

debug.label: Debug Logging
debug.tooltip: Enabling Debug will write a lot more data to the log. Use Max Body settings to control payloads sizes.

quiet.label: Quiet Logging
quiet.tooltip: Enabling Quiet makes the app not print anything to stdout. This is useful when a log file is enabled and you don't want logs spewing into a startup daemon too.

logFile.label: Application Log File
logFile.description: Path to the application log file.

httpLog.label: HTTP Log File
httpLog.description: Path to the HTTP log file.
httpLog.tooltip: Setting a log file path here will make the application write the HTTP logs to a dedicated file. The file format is in apache log. Highly recommended.

debugLog.label: Debug Log File
debugLog.description: Path to the debug log file.
debugLog.tooltip: Setting a log file path here will make the application write the debug logs to a dedicated file. Debug logs are written to the application log file when this is unset.

maxBody.label: Max Body Size
maxBody.description: Maximum body size for HTTP requests.
maxBody.tooltip: When debug is enabled, this setting limits the amount of payload data written to the log, to or from Notifiarr.com.

logFileMb.label: Log File Size
logFileMb.description: Maximum size of the log file before rotation.
logFileMb.tooltip: When rotation is enabled (setting Max Log File Count higher than 1), this setting controls how large a file must be to trigger rotation.

logFiles.label: Log File Count
logFiles.description: Number of log files to keep.
logFiles.tooltip: When this setting is 0 or 1, log file rotation is disabled. This setting applies to all log files, and will keep this many of each on disk.

noUploads.label: Deny Uploads
noUploads.description: Disabled allows Notifiarr.com administrators to make this client upload log files to the website. Enabled prevents log file uploads..
noUploads.tooltip: This setting controls the Notifiarr.com website and Notifiarr administrators' ability to trigger this client to upload log files to the website. Sometimes we need to see log entries while diagnosing problems and this trigger allows us to make the client upload the app and debug log files.

enabled.label: Service Checks
enabled.tooltip: Disable or enable monitoring all network and service checks right here.

parallel.label: Parallel Checks
parallel.tooltip: Normally running service checks 1 at a time is fine, but if you have more than 30 or 40, you may want to increase this.

logFile.label: Services Log File
logFile.description: Path to the services log file.
logFile.tooltip: The log file is used to store the service check results. If left unset, the service check output is written to the application log file.

path.label: File Path
path.description: Path to the file to watch.

urlbase.label: URL Base
urlbase.description: This application serves HTTP on / by default. You can change that by typing in something else here.

hostId.label: Host ID
hostId.description: The Host ID parameter is used to uniquely identify this client installation.
hostId.tooltip: Changing this value is discouraged; it should be found automatically. Do not copy this value to another Notifiarr client installation.

serial.label: Parallel Threads
serial.description: Disabling this setting will make the application use fewer go routines (threads) when gathering data from configured applications.
serial.tooltip: Spreads out CPU usage and lowers memory footprint.

retries.label: Retries
retries.description: Sometimes connections to Notifiarr.com fail. This controls how many times each request will be attempted in case of failures.

apt.label: APT Hook
apt.description: The Notifiarr Debian (and Ubuntu) packages include an APT integration.
apt.tooltip: The Notifiarr Debian (and Ubuntu) packages include an APT integration. This integration invokes every time an apt command is executed. To enable it, set this field to Enabled, and then enable the Package Manager integration on Notifiarr.com. This feature does not require the client to be running; it only requires the client deb package to be installed. This does not work on RHEL or non-Debian Linux.

timeout.label: Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for API requests to Notifiarr.com.

fileMode.label: Log File Unix Mode
fileMode.description: This is the unix file mode used when writing new log files.
fileMode.tooltip: Recommended values in order of openness: 0600, 0640, 0644

autoUpdate.label: Auto Update
autoUpdate.description: This is how often the application will check for updates. When one is found it will be installed automatically.

unstableCh.label: Unstable Channel
unstableCh.description: Enabling the unstable updates channel will make the application check the unstable website for auto-updates instead of GitHub.
unstableCh.tooltip: Only available to users with developer access.

phrase.ShowMoreDesc: Three authentication types are currently supported. Auth Proxy and No Password are only available if the current request comes from a valid, configured upstream IP address.
phrase.PasswordOnlyUsed: Username and Password are only used if Authentication Type is set to Password.
phrase.HeaderOnlyUsed: Auth Header is only used if Authentication Type is not set to Password.
phrase.AuthTypeChange: If Authentication Type changes, log out to complete the process.
phrase.EnterCurrentPassword: Enter your current password to make changes.
phrase.ProxyAuthDisabled: Proxy authentication is disabled because your upstream ({upstreamIp}) is not in the allowed upstreams list.
phrase.SeeWikiForAuthProxyHelp: See the wiki for instructions setting up an authentication proxy.

authType.label: Authentication Type
authType.description: Select how to authenticate with the client

option_desc.password: This is the default authentication type. Select the Password option to log into this application with a configured username and password. Only 1 username and password is supported. When selecting this option, you must fill in the username and new password fields. If this is the current authentication type you must also fill in the current password field to make changes.
option_desc.header: Select this option to log into this application using an HTTP header that contains a username. This is commonly known as proxy authentication. We have a wiki page that provides instructions to configure Nginx for this feature. When selecting this option, you must also select a header for the auth proxy. If no headers are displayed, then no valid headers were provided by the upstream proxy.
option_desc.noauth: This configuration is not recommended. The No Password authentication type allows any request from any configured upstream IP. It also works with an auth proxy to set the username. If no username is in the provided header, then it defaults to admin.

upstreams.label: Upstreams
upstreams.description: Trusted proxy IP or CIDR networks. Separate networks with spaces.
upstreams.tooltip: If Notifiarr client is behind a reverse proxy (swag, nginx, etc), then you should add that proxy's IP here. You can also specify full networks. This controls which IP is written to the web server log file, requester or X-Forwarded-For header. Required when using a request header for authentication, or when authentication is disabled.

header.label: Auth Header
header.description: Select the header containing your username
header.tooltip: This displays headers that are provided by the client or upstream that may be used for proxy authentication. This selection is used if Authentication Type is set to Header or No Password. Choose the header that displays your proper username. When using No Password, the header is used to set the username, but is not required.

UserInformation.title: User Information
UserInformation.YoureSoGifted: You're so gifted, and we love you! ðŸ’œ

Plex.title: Plex
Plex.description: The Plex integration is comprehensive, and many of the settings are configured on the Notifiarr.com website.

token.label: Token
token.tooltip: You may find directions for locating your Plex token at this Plex Article.

Tautulli.title: Tautulli
Tautulli.description: Tautulli provides a feature that allows you to give your Plex users custom usernames. By integrating Notifiarr client with Tautulli, those custom usernames will be displayed in your chat server notifications. When not enabled, Plex usernames or email addresses are used instead. This is entirely optional. The Notifiarr website also provides this same feature and allows you to map Plex users to custom names. You may also add a Tuaitulli instance here simply to monitor it with service checks.

apiKey.label: API Key
apiKey.description: API key for the Tautulli service.
